msDesc.head: Medical, grammatical, astrological etc. collections of Richard Stapledon; England (Oxford), c. 1430

msItem.title: Medical recipes, including against 'ryngeworm', epilepsy; and charms
Compotus manualis with commentary
msItem.incipit: CircumCisio Janus Epiphaniu sibi seqitur oc. Felicio Maurus Marcellus Sulpicius
msItem.colophon: Explicit compotus manualis, scriptus per R. Stapulton
msItem.note: The verses immediately following the Cisio Janus are (fol. 9v), 'A B C sunt extra d e f intra g supra'; see Wordsworth, Kalendar, 164, 179. For the Cisio Janus see ibid. 349. On fol. 10 is 'Filius esto dei', for which see ibid. 161/9 and Walther 6525, but many of the verses are different from those in Wordsworth. Fol. 37v is another copy of the text on fol. 9v, probably a reject leaf since fol. 37 is palimpsest.

msItem.author: John March (15th cent.)
msItem.title: De metris
msItem.incipit: Licet in presenti opusculo omnium sillabarum naturam declarare proponimus
msItem.explicit: et regit hoc ympnos sequentes, Martiris ecce dies
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit bona compilacio de metris, quam compilavit dominus Johannes Marche, capellanus, ad instanciam domini W. de Passurtone
msItem.note: Also in much shorter form in Cambridge, Trinity College, MS. O.5.4 (1285), fol. 59. Bale, Index, 233 cites a work called 'Scansiones metrarum' by this author but its incipit differs.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Including (f. 32v), 'Vera composicio domine de Beuchamp' (cf. 58v, 60r); 'Comitis Herdfordie, prenobilis in arte sururgico* (sic ; cf. 58r); 'Roberti Fermorarii de Kylyngwer ; (f. 33v), 'Buryson;' (f. 35v), 'Gilbertus;' (f. 120v), 'Sal quo usi sunt sacerdotes Egipti in diebus Elesay, et semper erant apparentes juvenes, et istud sal valet pro pluribus infirmitatibus in corpore humano;' (f. 293v), 'Collerium magistri Mauricii pro oculis;' (f. 300v), 'Pulvis preservativus, qui dicitur imperialis, quia imperatores Gentilium utuntur illo pulvere contra epidemiam et contra intoxicationes et omne venenum, contra morsum serpentum et aliorum animalium venenosorum, et dicitur in lingua Arabica Bechazaar, id est, a morte liberans.'
On fol. 117 is a recipe 'ad faciend' tabulas albas'. On fol. 120v is 'Ad faciendum sal quo usi sunt sacerdotes veteris legis'.

msItem.title: Grammatical text
msItem.rubric: Quatuor conjugationes Donati sub compendio
msItem.note: In the bottom margin of fol. 33 are two verses beg. 'Pulcrior esse putat', Sent. 22861 (= Pamphilius, v. 113 et seq.).

msItem.title: Medical verses on measures
msItem.incipit: Grana quater quinque scrupuli pro pondere

msItem.title: Herbal glossary
msItem.rubric: Nomina synonoma herbarum
msItem.incipit: Absintheum amarum idem gallice aloyne anglice weremode

msItem.author: Antonius Musa
msItem.title: De herba vettonica
msItem.rubric: Virtus vel curacio herbe betonice que habet medicamina quadraginta quatuor
msItem.incipit: Herba betonica contusa

msItem.title: Text on plantain
msItem.rubric: Virtus vel curacio arnoglosse que habet medicamina viginti quatuor
msItem.incipit: Herbe plantaginis
Nomen herbe saturion vel priapistus gallice foteroyle anglice standelgusse
Absintheum est herba acerima calida et sicca

msItem.rubric: For to knowe yueles that cometh of postoumes, hou it his clepet and of what compleccioun it haren

msItem.title: Text on urines
msItem.rubric: Viginti varii colores urinarum
msItem.incipit: Primus color albus est
msItem.rubric: Judicia urinarum
msItem.incipit: (fol. 114v) Urine qwite at morne
msItem.note: After art. 15, on fol. 72(73)v, are medical recipes beg. 'Ad maturandum quodcumque apostema in uno die si sit sub assellis.' The text breaks off at the end of the quire with catchword 'resine' and is continued in Balliol College, MS. 219 fols. 1-5

msItem.rubric: Signa que Ypocras fecit ad cognoscendum si infirmus sanari posset per medicinam vel non
msItem.note: Kibre, Hipp. Lat., p. 227 (XLVIII, Secreta; Signa sanitatis et mortis).

msItem.title: Text on urines
msItem.rubric: Nature urinarum, sub compendio
msItem.incipit: Prima urina colorata

msItem.author: Giles of Corbeil
msItem.title: De urinis
msItem.incipit: Dicitur urina quoniam fit renibus una

msItem.title: Commentary on Giles of Corbeil, De urinis
msItem.incipit: Liber quem proponimus legendum est ex antiquorum scripturis

msItem.title: Instructions for making a sundial
msItem.incipit: Instrumentum per quod sciuntur hore diei per umbram supra superficiem planam aque
msItem.note: With diagram.

msItem.incipit: Sal quo usi sunt sacerdotes Egipti

msItem.rubric: Anathomia de homine
msItem.note: Five chapters
msItem.incipit: Ex Aristotelis auctoritate expressum habemus

msItem.title: Text on urines
msItem.rubric: To knaw bestate of man and woman be thare water

msItem.title: Text on urines
msItem.rubric: Judicia urinarum, secundum Egidium
msItem.incipit: (fol. 130v) Quoniam circa urinas quinque attenduntur generalis et septem specialia

msItem.note: With diagrams.

msItem.title: Six verses
msItem.incipit: A nona noctis donec sit tertia lucis

msItem.title: On the four humours in the body
msItem.incipit: Humor est corpus liquidem fluidum
msItem.note: Extracts ascribed to Avicenna

msItem.title: Regimen sanitatis Salernitanum
msItem.incipit: Francorum regi scribit scola tota Salerni
msItem.bibl: For the version beginning 'Anglorum regi' see Walther 1039.

msItem.author: John of Mirfield
msItem.title: Breuiarium Bartholomaei
msItem.note: (extract, 8 chapters)
msItem.incipit: Oportet ipsum qui vult esse longevum
msItem.explicit: si non desistant quod percussionem non evadent
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit compendiosus tractatus de regimine sanitatis
msItem.note: See R. Creytens, AFP, 25 (1955), 371.

msItem.author: 'Gerardus Hispanus'
msItem.title: Flores Astronomiae
msItem.incipit: Cum animadverterem plures medicorum, in exhibicione medicinarum, terminos et motus corporum supercelestium ignorantes, graviter errare
msItem.explicit: Hoc autem est intelligendum secundum medium motum
msItem.finalRubric: Expliciunt flores astronomie Gerardi de Hispania, valentes in opere medicine

msItem.author: Ps.-Hippocrates
msItem.title: Astrologia medicorum
msItem.note: (tr. William of Moerbeke)
msItem.incipit: Dixit sapientissimus Ypocras, omnium medicorum peritissimus, Incius medicus est qui astronomiam ignorat Legens ergo libros Ypocratis, medicorom optimi, hunc librum parvum sed magis utilitatis reperi
msItem.bibl: Kibre, Hipp. Lat., 99, 103 (VII. Astrologia medicorum). L. Thorndike, 'The three Latin translations of the Pseudo-Hippocratic tract on astrological medicine', Janus, 49 (1960), 104-29, at 105 (list of manuscripts).

msItem.rubric: Tabule de modo graduandi seu calculandi medicinas secundum magistrum Arnaldum de Villa Nova
msItem.incipit: Notandum quod in omni medicamine vel cura, sive fiat per alterationem sive per evacuationem.

msItem.title: Medical-astrological text in eight chapters
msItem.note: Same text on fol. 181v, the fifth chaper varied.
msItem.incipit: Per primum numerum parem demonstratur quot sunt principaliter consideranda in egritudine acuta seu cronica

msItem.title: Text on the virtues of constellations and planets, with table
msItem.incipit: Quoniam secundum sapientes uultus inferiorum uultui superiorum

msItem.rubric: De infirmis si morientur vel vivent, de flebotomia, de temporibus dandi medicinas, per astronomiam
msItem.note: 14 chapters. Cap. i. De signatore infirmi. ii. De infirmitate, si est in spiritu vel corpore.

msItem.title: Sphaera Pythagorae
msItem.incipit: Collige per numerum quicquid cupis esse probandum
msItem.note: See L. E. Voigts, 'The Latin verse and Middle English prose texts on the sphere of life and death in Harley 3719', The Chaucer Review, 21 (1986), 291-305, at 298.

msItem.title: Astrological text
msItem.rubric: Tractatus brevis, sed perutilis de constellacionibus
msItem.incipit: Sciendum quod si quis nascitur in aliqua hora diei

msItem.title: Astrological texts on the zodiac, planets, days of the week etc.
msItem.note: Text on fols. 196v beg. 'Si volueris horam noctis invenire.' Text on fol. 197v beg. 'Cinthia mercurius Venus et Sol Mars love Satur', followed by 'Primo sciendum quod septem sunt planete', eTK 1112L, which is Hermes, Secreta. On fol. 199v is a table of complexions with verses, beg. 'Largus amans hilaris ridens', repeated from fol. 200; eTK 0811N, cf. Walther 10131. Also three verses beg. 'Anni sunt partes autumpnus yemps ver et estas.' They are also found on fol. 142.

msItem.title: Astrological text: tables related to the fixed stars, planets, and movable bodies
msItem.note: The last piece (fol. 201) beg. 'Diameter lune ad diametrum terre.' In the bottom margin are 'Componendi modus incausti nigri.1 Vncia gallarum mediate fit vncia gummi I Vncia vitrioli superaddat octo phalarni,' and 'Primo ponantur galle per quinque vel sex dies in aqua pluviali, deinde cope rose et simul stent quousque bene comisceantur et erga tempus in quo vis scribere impone gummam per septimam a(?).'

msItem.title: Short medical text
msItem.incipit: Medicina in duo dividitur, sciliciet ln theoricam et practicam
msItem.note: As far as the virtutes this is a commentary on Johannitius's Isagoge.
Explicatio verborum Arabicorum in medicina usitatorum
msItem.incipit: Alhosor, id est species zucrati duri
msItem.note: See also fol. 274, verses beg. 'Gaudet epar spodio'.

msItem.title: Antidotarium Nicholai
msItem.rubric: Nicholaus de compositis medicinis
msItem.incipit: Ego Nicholaus rogatus a quibusdam in practica studere volentibus

msItem.title: Seven verses on anatomy
msItem.incipit: Gaudet epar spodio mace cor cerebrum quoque misto

msItem.title: Text on the astrolabe
msItem.rubric: Tractatus astrolabii
msItem.incipit: Percipe altitudinem stelle vocate planete

msItem.title: Text on shorthand
msItem.incipit: Cum in arte notoria quamplura reseruntur

msItem.title: Trotula
msItem.rubric: Trotula mulierum
msItem.incipit: Cum auctor universitatis Deus in prima mundi origine
msItem.finalRubric: (fol. 291v) Explicit hec Trota multum mulieribus apta
msItem.note: Followed by four other verses.

On the development of this text see M. H. Green, 'The development of the Trotula', Revue d'histoire des textes, 26 (1996), 119-203. In the bottom margin of fol. 29 tv is a list of 'autores in medicinis'-'Galienus, Diascarides, Rasy, Damacenus, Lilium, Mesue, Cupho, Constantinus, Serapion, Avicenna, Algazel, Averoys, et alii sequaces.'

msItem.title: Astrological text
msItem.note: Quomodo inveniendus sit locus lunae in zodiaco
msItem.incipit: Nota quod si quis velit scire locum lune

msItem.rubric: Tabula ad sciendum quando flebotomia est bona vel mala vel mediocris

msItem.author: John of Burgundy
msItem.title: Tractatus de morbo epidemiae
msItem.rubric: Fidelis medici ad amicum bonum et sanum regiminis consilium, si audiatur, contra pestilenciam
msItem.incipit: Dilectissime frater et intellexi multum times pro instanti pestilencia
msItem.note: For copies additional to those listed by eTK see D. W Singer & A. Anderson, Catalogue of Latin and Vernacular Plague Texts in Great Britain and Eire (reprod. from typescript, Paris & London, 1950), no. 16

msItem.title: Treatise on rosemary
msItem.rubric: Virtutes quedam de rosa marina, collecte per quendam clericum de Salernia comitisse de Holand, quas ipsa misit filie sue Philippe desponsate Regi Anglie
msItem.incipit: Rosa marina arbor et herba calida et sicca

msItem.title: Herbal text
msItem.note: De virtutibus herbarum quarundam

history.provenance: Largely written by Richard Stapleton, Master of Balliol College, Oxford.

Given by him to Balliol College: erased inscription, fol. 2, legible by ultraviolet light: 'Istum librum dedit M. Ricardus Stapulton cathenandum in Iibraria ColJegii Balliolensis (cf. MSS. Balliol College 197 and 219). Stapulton was Master of Balliol c. 1430 and gave MSS. 197 and 219 to the College; see Mynors, Balliol, xx, 213 et seq., 282.
On fol. 305v is 'Cesely Margarete borne Joh'i[?] bolytowe' (s. xv), and 'Rychard Goodwyn' (s. xv). At the top of the same leaf is 'ijClxiiij levys.'
Probably later in the possession of John Dee (Roberts & Watson, MI77).
Kenelm Digby, 1603–1665. On fol. ii are Digby's motto and name.
history.acquisition: Donated to the Bodleian, 1634. There is a description of the manuscript in Gerard Langbaine's Adversaira, vol. iv, pp. 699-714.

recordHist.source: Description adapted from the Quarto Catalogue (W. D. Macray, Bodleian Library Quarto Catalogues IX: Digby Manuscripts, repr. with addenda by R. W. Hunt and A. G. Watson, 1999), and (decoration) Pächt and Alexander (1973). Quarto Catalogue, cols. 25–6 Quarto Catalogue, cols. 27–8 Quarto Catalogue (addenda), p. 18 Quarto Catalogue (addenda), p. 19 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 70

ref.title: MLGB3: Medieval Libraries of Great Britain

revisionDesc.change: Revised description to include all information in Quarto Catalogue.
